awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Refrigerant Ionic liquid Separation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will be to provide the refrigerant industry with the first commercial designs for separating complex, multi-component, azeotropic refrigerant mixtures for economical recycling. The American Innovation and Manufacturing Act authorizes the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to phase down production and consumption of refrigerants causing global warming by 85 percent over 15 years. The societal, economical, and environmental benefits are estimated to create thousands of jobs and increase manufacturing by billions of dollars in the U.S. while reducing venting and incineration, and subsequently global temperature rise. There are millions of metric tons of mixed refrigerants that cannot be reclaimed using current fractional distillation technology. The proposed ionic liquid extractive distillation technology will make possible the separation and reuse of these complex refrigerant mixtures. The startup company funded through this project will provide a novel separation technology to the refrigerant industry that is of strategic national interest. Outreach activities, especially toward the inclusion of women and underrepresented minorities will be supported through this project.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate that complex, multi-component, azeotropic refrigerant mixtures can be separated using ionic liquids, and that the products can meet industry standard specifications. Refrigerant mixture R-404A, used broadly throughout the commercial refrigeration industry (e.g., grocery stores) is a complex, ternary azeotropic mixture containing HFC-143a (1,1,1-trifluoroethane), which has a high global warming potential. HFC-143a will be one of the first refrigerants to be reused in new low global warming blends containing hydrofluoroolefins if the HFC-143a can be economically separated. Over 100 complex, multicomponent refrigerant mixtures exist in the market. This project will enable the development of processes, technologies, and systems designs required for industry to meet and exceed the phase down goals. The program objectives include the separation of R-404A into components, the creation of a process model, and testing of recovered R-404A from industry to understand the effects of impurities. The results will be used to develop a technoeconomic model and commercial scale designs that the team will build and/or license to the refrigerant industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Kansas Center for Research

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
As global temperatures rise, air-conditioning and refrigeration are becoming even more important for human comfort and food preservation. However, these systems use refrigerants that in many cases are hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), which are potent greenhouse gases with global warming potentials (GWP) thousands of times greater than CO2. The American Innovation & Manufacturing (AIM) Act and additional legislation is phasing down the production and consumption of HFCs in the US by 85% by 2036, but hundreds of millions of existing systems will require HFC refrigerants for servicing for many more decades, until the equipment reaches its end-of-life.  Under the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol, more than 100 additional countries will soon begin their HFC phasedown, which is not expected to be completed until the late 2040s. To minimize the global warming impacts of these refrigerants and meet global market demand during and beyond the global phasedown period, it is necessary to maximize the recovery and reclamation of HFC refrigerants while the world transitions to more sustainable alternatives. Unfortunately, much of the recoverable refrigerant in end-of-life systems that could be recycled today is either vented to the atmosphere, stockpiled, or incinerated. This is because no technology exists that is capable of efficiently separating these complex azeotropic mixtures into their individual components so that low-GWP refrigerants can be reused and high-GWP refrigerants can be repurposed. Without this technology, there is little economic incentive to recover refrigerants from existing systems, even though it is legally required in the US and other developed economies under the Montreal Protocol.

Through this STTR Phase I project, Icorium and the University of Kansas have demonstrated proof of concept for using extractive distillation with ionic liquids to separate azeotropic refrigerant mixtures into single components with commercial purities required for resale.  The pilot-scale extractive distillation located at the University of Kansas in the Wonderful Institute for Sustainable Engineering is the first-of-its-kind for refrigerant reclamation. Under the Phase I, the team developed a thorough understanding of thermophysical properties of key refrigerants and ionic liquids (ILs). Using this data, a rate-based computational modeling approach was developed to simulate the separation of binary and ternary commercial refrigerant blends. These models were validated and optimized to match pilot-scale experiments. With the knowledge gained, a screening method has been developed for identifying ILs with higher selectivity to reduce operating costs for future commercial development. Several promising candidates have been selected, studied, and modeled for use in commercial refrigerant separations, laying the groundwork for the subsequent development of a single-stream refrigerant reclamation process capable of efficiently separating complex refrigerant mixtures at the tens of millions of pounds per year scale.


Last Modified: 01/15/2025
Modified by: Kalin Baca
